conclusion: To find the temperature of the gas in state B, we can use the ideal gas law and the properties of the processes shown in the p-V diagram.
Identify the given information: State A: p_A = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 1 x 10^-3 m^3, T_A = 27 Â°C = 300 K; State B: p_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 1 x 10^-3 m^3.
Use the ideal gas law: pV = nRT where n is the number of moles, R is the universal gas constant, and T is the temperature in Kelvin.
Relate the states using the ideal gas law: (p_A V_A) / T_A = (p_B V_B) / T_B.
Substitute the known values: (3 x 10^5) x (1 x 10^-3) / 300 = (2 x 10^5) x (1 x 10^-3) / T_B.
Simplify the equation: (3 x 10^2) / 300 = (2 x 10^2) / T_B.
The temperature of the gas in state B is 200 K.
